info.game_comments:
1997 International Tournament semifinal game 3.
  From Stockholm, Sweden.

(2, 1).clue: Earth's tides are affected primarily by these 2 heavenly bodies

(3, 1).clue: This boxer had his first professional fight in 1960 under his given name, Cassius Clay

(4, 1).clue: This American's 1940 novel "For Whom the Bell Tolls" takes place near Segovia, Spain

(5, 1).clue: The telephone company named for this man was founded in 1877, a year after his invention

(6, 1).clue: On the night of April 14-15, 1912 this ship sank in the north Atlantic

(2, 2).clue: On some trees & shrubs, this protective covering slowly peels off & is replaced

(3, 2).clue: Flamboyant Italian slalom skier rhymingly dubbed "La Bamba"

(4, 2).clue: In her native Denmark, her book "Out of Africa" is called "Den Afrikanske Farm"

(5, 2).clue: American Indians sent signals using this vaporous substance

(6, 2).clue: Paris didn't take Helen to Paris; he took her to this city & instigated a war

(2, 3).clue: From "calm" to "hurricane", the Beaufort scale measures the strength of this

(3, 3).clue: She shot out of Sweden to win the world championship of women's golf in 1995 & 1996

(4, 3).clue: "A Child's Christmas in Wales" by this Welsh poet was published in 1955, 2 years after his death

(5, 3).clue: Shakespeare's Bassanio says Portia uses these facial features to send him "fair speechless messages"

(6, 3).clue: In 1802 this madame inherited her uncle's wax museum & went to London to set up an exhibition

(1, 4).clue: The United Republic of Tanganyika & Zanzibar

(2, 4).clue: The only poisonous snake in Great Britain, the common adder belongs to this snake family

(3, 4).clue: This man who led Argentina to the 1986 World Cup soccer title played for Italy's Napoli from 1984 to 1991

(4, 4).clue: Belgian author Georges Simenon wrote dozens of novels about this pipe-smoking police inspector

(5, 4).clue: These largest pachyderms communicate with infrasonic signals below the range of human hearing

(6, 4).clue: He was sent to bring Isolde to Cornwall to marry his uncle, King Mark

(2, 5).clue: These "laughing" scavengers will eat almost anything & will steal food even from lions

(3, 5).clue: 14-year-old Tara Lipinski upset this world champion at the 1997 U.S. Figure Skating Championship

(4, 5).clue: Stung by the hostile reaction to his 1862 novel "Fathers and Sons", this Russian moved to Baden-Baden

(5, 5).clue: In 1982 France Telecom introduced this system of home terminals linked by phone lines

(6, 5).clue: After the monarchy fell in 1792, this French statesman fled to England, then to the U.S.

(2, 1).clue: This current vice president served as an Army reporter during the Vietnam War

(3, 1).clue: He hasn't directed a feature film since 1977's "Star Wars"

(4, 1).clue: In 1759 Portugal banned the Jesuit order of this Christian church

(5, 1).clue: In the 930s Wang Kon unified this peninsula; it was divided again in the 1940s

(6, 1).clue: Traditionally, a female singer plays the role of Hansel in this Humperdinck opera

(1, 2).clue: In selecting her for the 1979 Peace Prize, the committee cited her work with refugees & children

(2, 2).clue: As commander of the Apollo 11 mission, he was the first man to set foot on the moon

(3, 2).clue: His 1983 film "Fanny and Alexander" was edited from a larger television miniseries

(4, 2).clue: The son of a copper miner, he initiated the Protestant Reformation

(5, 2).clue: Crusader Godfrey of Bouillon was chosen king of this holy city but was left in the soup by his allies

(6, 2).clue: Jules Massenet composed an opera based on this famous novel by Miguel de Cervantes

(1, 3).clue: This Italian won the 1938 Physics Award for discovering radioactive elements beyond uranium

(2, 3).clue: He painted the portrait seen here:[Arrangement in Grey and Black]

(3, 3).clue: He directed John Wayne in many westerns, including "The Searchers" & "Fort Apache"

(4, 3).clue: 2 of the forms of this Eastern religion are Theravada & Mahayana

(5, 3).clue: The town-dwellers known by this French term evolved into the Capitalist class of Marxist thought

(6, 3).clue: This hefty superstar tenor from Modena, Italy is often compared to Caruso

(1, 4).clue: This Russian physiologist's 1904 Nobel Prize was for his work on the physiology of digestion

(2, 4).clue: In 1916 this architect moved to Japan where he designed the Imperial Hotel in Tokyo

(3, 4).clue: This director's "Scream" pokes fun at horror films of the '80s, including his own Freddy Krueger movies

(4, 4).clue: This religion's chief god, the Jade Emperor, was officially sanctioned around 1000 A.D.

(5, 4).clue: Philosopher Albertus Magnus popularized the "Physics" & other works of this ancient Greek

(6, 4).clue: Originally, this composer's opera "Rigoletto" was titled "La Maledizione" ("The Curse")

(1, 5).clue: In 1969 Ragnar Frisch & Jan Tinbergen became the first to win in this newly established category

(2, 5).clue: This sharpshooter is the subject of the musical "Annie Get Your Gun"

(3, 5).clue: This French director appears as a passerby who points out Belmondo to the police in his 1959 film "Breathless"

(4, 5).clue: The main religion on the island of Bali is a mixture of local religious rites & this major religion

(5, 5).clue: Frankish king Charles Martel & the Schlegerbund, a group of Swabian knights, took their names from this tool

(6, 5).clue: Originally, this Czech composer's opera "The Bartered Bride" contained some spoken dialogue

(0, 0).clue: This playwright born in Colonus around 496 B.C. wrote one of his finest plays when he was 90
